Dear Maria Elaina Lessnau:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/6/24 Supervisor bit Youth K and Staff 1 scratched him.
Investigation Interviews:
I contacted Complainant on 4/8/24. She said her sergeant
directed her to contact centralized intake, but she did not know
why. She expressed no additional licensing concerns.
MISACWIS indicates Complainant told centralized intake the mark
on Youth K’s hand did not resemble a human bite.
I notified Youth K’s Foster Care Worker of the investigation
assignment, and she expressed no additional licensing concerns.
I received notification the assigned Government Worker 1 would
return to work on 4/9/24.
I notified Chief Administrator (CA) and Residential Director of
the allegation via text. Both were out of the state on holiday. In
their absence, Clinical Director was the identified person in
charge.
I arrived on-site at the facility on 4/8/24 and interviewed Youth K.
I observed a curved ½” abrasion on the right side of his hand right
hand and two ½” faded scars on his right forearm and took photos
of the abrasions. Youth K said Supervisor bit him and caused the
mark on his hand, and Staff 1 scratched him causing the marks on
his forearm.
Youth K has resided at Christ Child House for six months. He
said the incident occurred on 4/6/24 after he returned from AWOL.
Supervisor and Staff 1 came into his room and told him he could
2

not leave his room. “They pushed me back in my room. Staff 1
got on top of me on my bed and held my shirt. He brought up his
fist. I fought him off of me.” Youth K said Staff 1 scratched him
when Staff 1 was in his room. “Supervisor grabbed me and threw
me in the closet. I tussled with Supervisor. He bit me. I got out
and Staff 1 blocked and pushed me back in. Supervisor asked for
another staff. Staff 2 was sitting in a chair in the hallway. The next
morning, I climbed out my bedroom window and jumped off the
roof. The police found me an hour later and brought me back.
They called an ambulance for my bite and cuts. They (hospital
medical staff) gave me a pill.” MDHHS came to the hospital.
I interviewed Supervisor 2. He said he observed Youth K at
12:30am on 4/7/24 after the incident, Youth K reported no injuries
and he saw no injuries at that time. I Asked why Youth K went to
the hospital on 4/7/24, he did not know the reason and said the
police called the ambulance and they transported him.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1 on 4/11/24.
She has worked at the facility for 18 months and witnessed the
incident. Staff 2 said Youth K returned from AWOL on 4/6/24 and
was brought back by police. The police escorted him upstairs to
his room and “told me, Supervisor and Staff 1 to make sure Youth
K stays in his room. Youth K was upset that his shoes were taken
to help prevent another AWOL. He lifted his window and tried to
get out. Supervisor and Staff 1 went into this room and redirected
him. I stood at his doorway and said, ‘No. You can’t come out.’
Youth K cried and threw stuff (a pillow). Staff 1 was on my left,
Supervisor on my right and I was in the middle. Youth K charged
at Supervisor and Staff 1. They told him to go back and put their
hands out in front of them. Youth K cussed and threatened to get
them fired and hit them in the face. He charged his head toward
Staff 1 to get through. Youth K grabbed Staff 1’s legs and Staff 1
tried to get free. Youth K pulled Staff 1 to the floor. Staff 1 fell to
one side and Youth K fell to the other side. Staff 1 hopped up and
moved back. Supervisor grabbed Youth K’s hand, helped him up
off the floor and told him to sit on the bed. I knew Staff 1 was hurt
because he was shaking…I went downstairs to get assistance
from Staff 3…Youth K had no injuries and was not bleeding.”
Staff 2 denied that Supervisor or Staff 1 pushed or touched Youth
K. At no point were Supervisor or Staff 1 with Youth K in his
closet, and Staff 1 was never on top of him on his bed. Staff 2
denied Supervisor or Staff 1 threatening Youth K verbally. On the
contrary, she said Youth K threatened to “tear up staff’s cars,
throw a brick into Supervisor’s truck and get his mother and
3

grandmother to jump me.” Staff 2 said Supervisor did not bite
Youth K or throw him in a closet and Staff 1 did not hold him by
his shirt.
On 4/11/24 I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government
Worker 1. He has worked at the facility for 15 years. Government
Worker 1 read the allegations aloud. Supervisor responded, “I
never bit him.” After police brought Youth K back from AWOL, he
said they “basically told us to keep him in the building.”
Supervisor said Youth K went into a room and wanted out. “Staff
1 tried to keep him from closing the door. Youth K raised his
speaker up to throw it at the window. Staff 1 spoke nicely and
caring to him. Youth K tapped Staff 1’s chest lightly, saying “Let
me go.” Youth K wanted out of the room and out of the building.
He lunged at Staff 1 again and wrapped his arms around Staff 1’s
knee. Staff 1 tried to get free and fell on Youth K who was on the
bed. Staff 1 got off quickly. We were at the door supporting Staff
1.”
Supervisor denied anyone was in the closet. He said Staff 1 did
not grab or pin Youth K’s arms behind his back. Supervisor
denied touching any part of Youth K’s body. He saw no injuries
on Youth K and said no injuries were reported to him. He denied
he or Staff 1 made any verbal threats toward Youth K. On the
other hand, Supervisor said Youth K threatened to throw
something through his car window and beat my ‘old ass’ if I
touched him.” The next morning Youth K jumped out a window
and AWOLed again.
Staff 1 could not be interviewed immediately as Residential
Director said he was injured after Youth K grabbed his legs and
pulled him to the floor and has been on medical leave since this
incident with a suspected torn meniscus requiring surgery.
Residential Director confirmed youths can open their second-floor
bedroom windows, climb onto the roof and jump to the ground.
The fire inspector inspected the building and prohibited putting
locks on the windows as they would cause a fire hazard.
Government Worker 1 interviewed Doctor via phone on 4/23/24.
Doctor indicated the mark on Youth K’s hand looked like a
scratch, not a human bite.
On 4/24/24 I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1
via video conference. He has worked at the facility for four years
and is on medical leave indefinitely due to an anterior cruciate
ligament injury that happened the day of this incident.
4

Staff 1 recalled Youth K went into his room, tried to close the door
and acted as if he was going to climb out the window. He went
behind his door near the closet and tied bedsheets together,
cussing and threatening staff. Youth K picked up speakers and
was about to throw them at the window. Supervisor knocked the
speakers out of his hand. “Youth K shoved Supervisor. I held onto
Supervisor and backed up. Youth K tackled me, and I heard a
crunch in my knee. I went down and used my body weight to get
up. We (Staff 1 and Youth K) tried to get up.” Youth K started
crying about his family. Supervisor and Staff 1 tried to de-escalate
him… I went to the hospital.”
I interviewed Staff 3 jointly with Government Worker 1 via video
conference. She has worked part-time at the facility for 13 years.
Staff 3 said the police advised staff to keep Youth K in his room
because they did not want to return to the facility. Youth K was
subsequently placed on “runaway status” meaning his shoes were
confiscated to discourage him from truanting. Staff 3 said she did
not witness anything that happened with Supervisor, Staff 1 and
Youth K in the youth’s room. When she arrived in the residential
hallway, she said Staff 1 was already injured and she was
assigned to monitor Youth K in his room. Staff 3 said she did not
see any injuries on Youth K and he did not tell her he was bitten
by Supervisor or mishandled by Staff 1.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident report by Supervisor dated 4/6/24 at 6pm indicated
Youth K was in his room and wanted to close his door all
the way. He picked up his speaker and threatened to break
his window. Supervisor grabbed the speaker out of his
hand with Staff 1’s assistance. Youth K continuously tried
to exit the room pushing staff in the process and refusing
verbal directives.
• I reviewed the Discipline and Behavior Management Policy
which indicates Christ Child House specifically prohibits
physical abuse and verbal abuse of residents by staff.
Video Review:
There are no cameras inside of the youths’ rooms. Footage of the
second-floor hallway on 4/6/24 from 6:25pm – 6:50pm showed
Youth K walking in and out of rooms while Staff 1 sat in the hall.
Youth K entered a room at the end of the hall and Supervisor and
Staff 1 followed him inside. Staff 2 appears. Staff 3 goes into the
room. Staff 1 exits the room limping. Supervisor exits the room.
5

Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis Youth K had two abrasions on his right hand. The doctor who
examined him stated the mark(s) on his hand looked like
scratches and not a human bite. Two staff witnessed the series of
events in Youth K’s room. All staff denied that Supervisor or Staff
1 bit, pushed or scratched the youth. It could not be determined
when or how Youth K’s hand was scratched.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii)Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Supervisor and Staff 1 each verbally threatened bodily harm to
Youth K.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth K said Staff 1 told him if he ever catches Youth K in the
street he will do “something” to him, which Youth K took as a
threat. He also said Supervisor told him he would “break every
bone” in his body.
Supervisor denied that he or Staff 1 made any threats toward
Youth K. He did say Youth K threatened to throw something
through his car window and beat his “old ass” if Supervisor
touched him.
Staff 2 denied that Staff 1 or Supervisor verbally threatened Youth
K. On the contrary, she said Youth K threatened to hit them in
their faces and get them fired.
6

Staff 1 denied threatening harm to Youth K. However, he said
Youth K was threatening to “kick our butts.”
Documentation reviewed:
• I reviewed the Discipline and Behavior Management Policy
which indicates Christ Child House specifically prohibits
physical abuse and verbal abuse of residents by staff.
Analysis Interviews did not support that any staff threatened Youth K with
bodily harm.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion
Title plan; prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162
Section (11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Supervisor and Staff 1 blocked Youth K from exiting his room to
prevent him from AWOLing.
Investigation There are no video cameras inside the youth bedrooms.
Interviews:
Youth K said Supervisor and Staff 1 came into his room and told
him he could not leave his room. “I tried to leave through the
door. They blocked me from leaving.”
Staff 2 said she was aware the licensing rules prohibits staff from
preventing a youth from exiting his room. In this instance, she
said staff followed the directive from police officers instead of
following the rule explaining, “We did it for Youth K’s safety.”
Supervisor said, “The police basically told us to keep Youth K in
the building.” He was aware the licensing rule prohibits staff from
preventing a youth from exiting a room or the building but said
staff violated the rule to keep Youth K safe.
Staff 1 denied that he or Supervisor blocked Youth K from exiting
his room.
7

Analysis Interviews indicated police escorted Youth K upstairs to his room
and advised staff to keep him in his room or the building. Staff
were aware that preventing a youth from exiting his room was
prohibited but said they did it anyway to keep Youth K safe.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
